text:
Copy task will strip permissions on the destination files. Specificly execute 
permission disapears upon coppying. This renders the copy command void in 
instances where executable files need to be moved. I am assuming this is a unix 
related problem.
creator: misko@hevery.com
misko@hevery.com
text:
On more indepth examination, I noticed that JAR, and ZIP also strip execute 
permissions. Unziping a ZIP file with unix unzip command creates all the files 
and directories with execute permission removed.

creator: tim@adjective.org
text:
See: http://jakarta.apache.org/ant/manual/CoreTasks/zip.html
"Note that file permissions will not be stored in the resulting zipfile."

Java does not provide an API to determine the platform specific file-
permissions.

The Copy task has no way of knowing if the original file was executable, and 
thus no way to preserve the execute bits.

Note that in 1.4 Zip does (IIRC) keep execute permissions on directories.

creator: bodewig@apache.org
text:
There is no way to determine the current file permissions from within Java,
therefore Ant cannot determine (and later restore) them, sorry.

As for the ZIP task in Ant 1.4 - yes it explicitly sets the execute permissions
for directories, but it does so because it know that they are directories, not
because it had access to the original permissions.
